story:
ABOUT US

 Reaching Our Community Adult Daycare is a 501 (c) (3) Non-Profit organization providing supervised care as an alternative to long-term care.

THE STORY

I have experienced first-hand how hard it is to deal with the difficult task of what to do with your loved one when tragedy has occurred. In 2006, I lost my mother to bone cancer, and was faced with the difficult decision to either place her in a nursing home or get hospice care. After researching, I preferred to stay home with her myself, but also had the risk of losing my job. While caring for my mom and looking for resources, I discovered the great need for an alternate way to care for a loved one. From this experience, I gained a passion for being the loving person to care for the elderly in their time of need. I enjoy helping and caring for people. Shortly after our marriage in 2007, my husband and I decided we would take on the great task of opening an adult daycare to create “extraordinary experiences” for the disabled young and seniors. We believe that stimulating the mind, strengthening the body, and enhancing creativity is beneficial at any age in life.

Many seniors believe they are capable of caring for themselves when they come upon old age, but you notice the symptoms, indications, or warning signs that they may need help at home with simple tasks they would normally handle on their own.  For instance, you notice that they are experiencing weight loss due to poor eating habits, poor hygiene and housekeeping, urinary problems, strong smell of urine in their house, unexplained injuries or bruising, frequent falls which all could be a result of neglect. Your love one would probably just tell you “Everything is fine.” or “There is no need to worry.” These are just a few signs that your loved one needs a little daily help.

 GIVE HOPE

If your loved one has any of these symptoms, the weight of caring for your family member or friend could become a responsibility for you to find a way to get this person some help. Getting them some assistance does not mean that they would have to abandon their comfortable home and loving family. Most seniors, like my mom , prefer to remain in the home. Removing them from the home could strip them of their independence, which often leads to depression and could cause their quality of life to decline even more.  We all know, "There is no place like home."

WHAT YOUR DONATIONS WILL BE USED FOR

Reaching Our Community Adult Daycare, would allow your loved one to come spend the day during regular working hours in the loving care of people dedicated and passionate for what they do. We will provide compassionate and considerate care while you, the caregiver, can handle any business or just rest if you need to.  Also, if our client becomes ill and unable to attend daycare no need to worry we will provide in-home care. 24hrs if necessary to keep our customers comfortable and safe. We care.

Our vision is to promote healthy seniors through championship, wellness, and nutrition while supporting their independence.

Your donations to this start-up project is needed.  All funds will be used to support the lease or rent for our location, the purchase of equipment, utilities, computers, activities, furniture, transportation services, meal on wheels, insurance, payroll, licenses, etc.

Thank you in advance for your support.

story:
Version Française

 daana (Google Non-Profit ID: 344-054-1563) provides 'pay-it-forward' wellness activities in spaces that are donated by people all around the world . 
Join us with this game-changer movement for creating generous and healthy communities worldwide!

Hi, my name is Bhaskar, and I would like to introduce you to daana:


What:

wellness : open-source  .  by-donation  .  world-wide


How:


Why:

  1. Health: Time, distance, money and any kind of self-perceived limitations are no longer reasons to not practice.
  2. Generosity: The word 'daana' means “cultivating the virtue of generosity by giving”. Generosity is the antidote to stress. You cannot be stressed and generous at the same time.
  3. Community: Built on a foundation on good health, wisdom and compassion, the classes can be yoga, meditation, dance, art, cooking, Tai Chi, dialogue circles, social projects - Essentially anything 'pay-it-forward' that uplifts the human condition.

90% of the revenue from every class goes to the teachers and champions. The 10% is to cover our costs and make by-donation wellness activities available to all. The foundation of this initiative, is generosity:


Why Crowd Funding?

We need to raise $90k to pay for:

  • 'Uber for Wellness' Website + App: A fully functional smart-device friendly website and app with geo-locator, calendar view, activity filters, on-line registration/ survey/ donation, automatic notifications and teacher payment etc. is $55K total. We've had it quoted from five sources (with a history of creating this kind of web and app) and this is the best we found. It needs to be simple and easy to use, otherwise people will not use it.
  • Press & Publicity: $25K will go towards implementing a viral marketing strategy in the initial launch cities. This is actually in the low end of what is required to do this properly (we got this quoted four times).
  • Train Champions: The remaining $10K will be to cover the travel and expenses for training the local champions properly.

With the funding, here is the daana student experience:

  • Launch smart-device friendly daana website or app.
  • See all the 'pay-it-forward' activities in your area via geo-locator and calendar.
  • Click on any event for more information (e.g. picture of the space, any particular circumstances like stair cases, pets etc., profile of the teacher, type of class and space capacity).
  • If there is room, register for the class on-line, for free.
  • Two hours after the class, respond to prompt by the smart device to rate the practice, comment and offer an on-line donation (safer than cash, environmentally friendly and hassle free).
48 hours after each class an email is automatically sent to the respective teacher and champion, with a review of the class. 90% of the revenue generated from that class is sent directly to the respective teacher's account. The teacher then contributes 20% to their local Champion.
Ancient system meets modern modern technology:


The breakdown

At the moment, in about 6 months there are already over 22 daana classes per week around Montreal, with 8 more on the way! We know this works and that there is a demand for it. 

For phase 2, with the proper technology, we would like to pilot the project in several major national and international cities (Toronto, Vancouver, New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, London, Paris, Dubai, Hong Kong, etc.) 


Perks (revamped!)

With the proper infrastructure in place, we target having 12,500 students per week in three years. Divide the $90K funding required by 12,500; it means that, in three years, one new person will have access to daana classes, for every 7 dollars you contribute. That's the real perk :)

Also, we've put together several awesome gifts that are unique for this project. All gifts will be shipped three weeks after the end of the campaign. 

daana 'generosity' T-Shirts: This is how to win amazing friends and influence people :)

daana 'generosity' bracelet: (3 shown above) Made with rose quartz (unconditional love), bodhi seeds (wisdom), onyx (resilience) and sandalwood (inner peace). Made only for this Indiegogo campaign, so that we can recognize each other on the streets ;)


 daana 'generosity' impact resistant glass bottle: (2 shown above) How gorgeous is this! (buh-bye plastic)

Open Yoga practice CD: Taught by multiple award winning 'yogi-preneur' and daana (and BODHI) founder Bhaskar Goswami, with live original music by four-time grammy nominated Adrian Carr. The art of seduction - just have one of these lying around on your coffee table :)


Other gifts: We will be hosting a Legacy Weekend Retreat at Le Couvent in the beautiful mountain village of Val Morin (lecouventvalmorin.com) in Quebec, Canada. This is where you can meet all the key daana supporters and together we explore the theme of 'legacy'. This includes meals, accommodation, weekend retreat content, and transportation from Montreal YUL airport.


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Join us! Host, teach and practice with us. We would love to add your class to our site. It can be any kind of wellness activity that is 'pay-it-forward' (contact us)
  • Become a part of the daana community (globaldaana.org --> scroll to bottom of page)
  • daana activism:  Engage bloggers, journalists, celebrities, maybe you (!) to write and tweet about us. 
  • Lend us your voice! Invite friends to this page, 'like' and share daana posts and videos on Facebook, follow daana on Twitter (#daana #playitbackwards #generosity). You can use the Indiegogo share tools.
  • If you have any cool, creative ways to make this even better, let's brain dance! Contact us: info@globaldaana.org
  • If you happen to have any friends or family members who 'get it', kindly request them to contribute to this campaign.
  • By being engaged in this project enough to read this far, you are already helping. Thank you :)
A narrative of a new daana wellness participant, Antoine. His story and discovery of daana:


daana supporters

Left to right:

Kiarash Amin - daana research savant

Kirsten Gayk-Lemay - daana social media rock star, info@globaldaana.org

Stanley Norris - daana grassroots movement yogi

Elina St-Onge - daana videography and writer extraordinare 

Bhaskar Goswami - daana maestro, bhaskar@globaldaana.org

Caroline Goyer - daana operations guru, caroline@globaldaana.org

Jeevan Dhamindra- daana design jedi

Marie-Pier Lambert - daana fan (this could be you!)

Harun Kinali - daana web development sensei


Also:

Dave Sullivan - daana video campaign hero

Ganesha (Anthony Neto) - daana 'we the hero' mystic

Jamie Benizri - daana legal samurai (Legal Logik)

Reina Hallab - daana PR-Marketing devotee (Raw Marketing)

Carole Asswad - daana peace warrior


Version Française

• corps en santé • esprit en paix • pour tous •


daana (Google Non-Profit ID: 344-054-1563) une nouvelle initiative de bien-être accessible à l'internationale avec un système ‘Payez-au-suivant’

Joignez-vous à nous afin de créer des communautés basées sur la générosité et la santé partout dans le monde!

Bonjour! Je m’appelle Caroline et j’aimerais vous présenter daana :


Quoi:

Bien-être : open-source • par donation • mondial

Comment:

Étape 1: Un hôte offre un espace;

Étape 2: Un professeur est assigné au cours;

Étape 3: L'étudiant recherche pour un cours et s'enregistre; 

Étape 4: L'étudiant assiste au cours et ensuite offre un don au professeur.

Pourquoi:

1.  Santé – le temps, la distance, l’argent et toute autre limitation perçue deviennent des raisons non-valables pour ne pas pratiquer;

2.  Générosité – Ici, les hôtes offrent généreusement leur espace; les professeurs sont généreux en guidant leur cours; et, les participants sont généreux en faisant un don pour le bien-être des étudiants futurs—‘Payez-au-suivant’; 

3.  Communauté – Fondés sur une base de santé et de générosité, ces espaces communautaires peuvent être utilisés pour toutes activités inspirantes, telles que le Tai-Chi, la danse, la musique, des cercles de dialogue, projets sociaux, et plus encore. Ceci est une excellente façon de construire et de soutenir les communautés locales.


Pourquoi le socio-financement:

Nous demandons 90K$ afin de financer :

·  Un site web + application mobile (55K$) – plate-forme technologique conviviale et instinctive avec localisateur géographique, système d’inscription électronique, formulaire pour dons en ligne, etc.

·  Communications & Marketing (25K$) – budget nécessaire afin de bien promouvoir dans chaque région et continuer de développer le projet;

·  Former les ‘Champions’ (10K$) – ce budget est conservé pour bien entraîner les ‘Champions’ des différentes régions.


Ventilation:

Phase 1 : Provincial - Nous avons commencé avec le yoga et avons présentement une vingtaine de cours hebdomadaires sur l'île de Montréal. Et, ça ne cesse d’augmenter!

Phase 2 : National - Une fois que les outils technologiques seront développés adéquatement, daana pourra facilement se répandre dans les autres villes majeures du Canada

Phase 3 : International - Lorsque daana sera bien fondé dans les premières villes, les États-Unis et le reste du monde pourront également bénéficier des cours daana!

Les collaborateurs de daana!

Community: Built on a foundation
     on good health, wisdom and compassion, the classes can be yoga, meditation, dance, art, cooking, Tai Chi,
     dialogue circles, social projects - Essentially anything 'pay-it-forward' that uplifts the human condition.


90% of the revenue from every class goes to the teachers and champions. The 10% is to cover our costs and make by-donation wellness activities available to all. The foundation of this initiative, is generosity:




Why Crowd Funding?



We need to raise $90k to pay for:


'Uber for
     Wellness' Website + App: A fully functional smart-device friendly
     website and app with geo-locator, calendar view, activity filters, on-line registration/ survey/ donation, automatic notifications and teacher payment etc. is $55K total. We've had it quoted from
     five sources (with a history of creating this kind of web and app) and this is the best we found. It needs to be simple and easy to use,
     otherwise people will not use it.

Press & Publicity: $25K will go towards
     implementing a viral marketing strategy in the initial launch cities. This
     is actually in the low end of what is required to do this properly (we got
     this quoted four times).

Train Champions: The remaining $10K will be
     to cover the travel and expenses for training the local champions
     properly.




With the funding, here is
the daana student experience:

Launch smart-device friendly daana website or app.
See all the 'pay-it-forward' activities in your area via geo-locator and calendar.
Click on any event
     for more information (e.g. picture of the space, any particular
     circumstances like stair cases, pets etc., profile of the teacher, type
     of class and space capacity).
If there is room, register for the class on-line, for free.
Two hours after the class, respond to prompt by the smart device to rate the practice, comment
     and offer an on-line donation (safer than cash, environmentally friendly and
     hassle free).


48 hours after each class an email is automatically sent to the respective teacher and champion, with a review of the
     class. 90% of the revenue generated from that class is sent directly to the respective teacher's
     account. The teacher then contributes 20% to their local Champion.



Ancient system meets modern modern technology:

The breakdown
 At the moment, in about 6 months there are already over 22 daana classes per week around Montreal, with 8 more on the way! We know this works and that there is a demand for it. 
For phase 2, with the proper technology, we would like to pilot the project in several major national and international cities (Toronto, Vancouver, New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, London, Paris, Dubai, Hong Kong, etc.) 

    
Perks (revamped!)


With the proper infrastructure in place, we target having 12,500 students per week in three years. Divide the $90K funding required by 12,500; it means that, in three years, one new person will have access to daana classes, for every 7 dollars you contribute. That's the real perk :)


Also, we've put together several awesome gifts that are unique for this project. All gifts will be shipped three weeks after the end of the campaign. 




daana 'generosity' T-Shirts: This is how to win amazing friends and influence people :)



daana 'generosity' bracelet: (3 shown above) Made with rose quartz (unconditional love), bodhi seeds (wisdom), onyx (resilience) and sandalwood (inner peace). Made only for this Indiegogo campaign, so that we can recognize each other on the streets ;)

 daana 'generosity' impact resistant glass bottle: (2 shown above) How gorgeous is this! (buh-bye plastic)


Open Yoga practice CD: Taught by multiple award winning 'yogi-preneur' and daana (and BODHI) founder Bhaskar Goswami, with live original music by four-time grammy nominated Adrian Carr. The art of seduction - just have one of these lying around on your coffee table :)
Other gifts: We will be hosting a Legacy Weekend Retreat at Le Couvent in the beautiful mountain village of Val Morin (lecouventvalmorin.com) in Quebec, Canada. This is where you can meet all the key daana supporters and together we explore the theme of 'legacy'. This includes meals, accommodation, weekend retreat content, and transportation from Montreal YUL airport.


    Other Ways You Can Help 


Join us! Host, teach and practice with us. We would love to add your class to our site. It can be any kind of wellness activity that is 'pay-it-forward' (contact us)
Become a part of the daana community (globaldaana.org --> scroll to bottom of page)

daana activism:  Engage bloggers, journalists, celebrities, maybe you (!) to write and tweet about us. 
Lend us your voice! Invite friends to this page, 'like' and share daana posts and videos on Facebook, follow daana on Twitter (#daana #playitbackwards #generosity). You can use the Indiegogo share tools.
If you have any cool, creative ways to make this even better, let's brain dance! Contact us: info@globaldaana.org
If you happen to have any friends or family members who 'get it', kindly request them to contribute to this campaign.
By
being engaged in this project enough to read this far, you are already helping.
Thank you :)


A narrative of a new daana wellness participant, Antoine. His story and discovery of daana:






daana supporters

Left to right:Kiarash Amin - daana research savantKirsten Gayk-Lemay - daana social media rock star, info@globaldaana.orgStanley Norris - daana grassroots movement yogiElina St-Onge - daana videography and writer extraordinare Bhaskar Goswami - daana maestro, bhaskar@globaldaana.orgCaroline Goyer - daana operations guru, caroline@globaldaana.org
Jeevan Dhamindra- daana design jedi
Marie-Pier Lambert - daana fan (this could be you!)Harun Kinali - daana web development senseiAlso:Dave Sullivan - daana video campaign heroGanesha (Anthony Neto) - daana 'we the hero' mysticJamie Benizri - daana legal samurai (Legal Logik)Reina Hallab - daana PR-Marketing devotee (Raw Marketing)Carole Asswad - daana peace warrior
Version Française


• corps en santé • esprit en paix
• pour tous •
daana (Google Non-Profit ID: 344-054-1563) une nouvelle initiative de bien-être accessible à l'internationale avec un système ‘Payez-au-suivant’Joignez-vous à nous afin de créer des communautés basées sur la générosité et la santé partout dans le monde!Bonjour! Je m’appelle
Caroline et j’aimerais vous présenter daana :

Quoi: 
Bien-être : open-source • par donation • mondial
Comment: Étape 1: Un hôte offre un espace;Étape 2: Un professeur est assigné au cours;Étape 3: L'étudiant recherche pour un cours et s'enregistre; Étape 4: L'étudiant assiste au cours et ensuite offre un don au professeur.
Pourquoi:
1.  Santé – le
temps, la distance, l’argent et
toute autre limitation perçue deviennent des raisons non-valables pour ne pas pratiquer;
2.  Générosité – Ici,
les hôtes offrent généreusement leur espace; les professeurs sont généreux en
guidant leur cours; et, les participants sont généreux en faisant un don pour
le bien-être des étudiants futurs—‘Payez-au-suivant’;  
3.  Communauté – Fondés
sur une base de santé et de générosité, ces espaces communautaires peuvent être
utilisés pour toutes activités inspirantes, telles que le Tai-Chi, la danse, la
musique, des cercles de dialogue, projets sociaux, et plus encore. Ceci est une
excellente façon de construire et de soutenir les communautés locales. 
Pourquoi
le socio-financement: 
Nous demandons 90K$ afin de financer : 
· 
Un site web + application mobile
(55K$) – plate-forme
technologique conviviale et instinctive avec localisateur géographique, système
d’inscription électronique, formulaire pour dons en ligne, etc. 
· 
Communications & Marketing (25K$) – budget nécessaire afin de bien
promouvoir dans chaque région et continuer de développer le projet; 
· 
Former les ‘Champions’ (10K$) – ce budget est conservé pour bien
entraîner les ‘Champions’ des différentes régions.
Ventilation: 
Phase 1 : Provincial - Nous avons commencé
avec le yoga et avons présentement une vingtaine de cours hebdomadaires sur
l'île de Montréal. Et, ça ne cesse d’augmenter! 
Phase 2 : National - Une fois que les
outils technologiques seront développés adéquatement, daana pourra facilement
se répandre dans les autres villes majeures du Canada

Phase 3 : International - Lorsque daana sera
bien fondé dans les premières villes, les États-Unis et le reste du monde
pourront également bénéficier des cours daana! 
Les
collaborateurs de daana!

story:
Make the healthy choice the easy choice. 

Give 5,000 student textbooks to
“CYCLE Kids” in elementary schools across the nation.
Give teachers a well-researched and highly successful 4th and 5th grade
bike and nutrition curriculum developed in conjunction with
Boston University academics.

Who is a CYCLE Kid?
For the first time, Antonio felt like he was good at something. Learning to ride a bike made Antonio realize he could be successful. He began focusing on his academic work, making friends, and working with adult mentors to help him acclimate to his new community. Becoming physically active and learning how to eat well became a foundation of change for Antonio. Now, he is a student at a local community college…and he rides his bike to school!

Our goal is to help children realize the healthy choice is the easy choice.

Mission
Building healthy, productive communities, starting with children and families. 

Stories where a bike provides a right of passage for a child can be seen throughout the 11-year history of the CYCLE Kids program.  The CYCLE Kids program gets kids focusing on better physical activity and nutrition habits. When kids do this, there is a shift toward better academic performance. Teaching kids to ride bikes gets them to reach outside their comfort zones, building their confidence to make new friends and try new things. 

CYCLE Kids reaches 3,500 children every year, and over 
13,000 children since inception.

What Your Donation Will Do
Our Indiegogo Campaign Goal is to raise funds to produce the 5,000 student textbooks and teaching curriculum for the expanded CYCLE Kids program.

Your donation will help us hire a writer, a designer and an illustrator to produce our new curriculum and student textbooks. It will also help digitally print 5,000 student textbooks and the teaching curriculum. 

Your donation will help us give schools important tools to
build healthy productive communities, starting with their children and families. 

The Program - Bikes and Books that Shift Gears for Healthy Kids
CYCLE Kids gets kids riding bikes in school. We provide the bikes, curriculum, and training for teachers, and even local police officers.  The kids learn about nutrition, they learn how to ride a bike, they get exercise and most importantly, they develop confidence and independence, and realize exercise can be fun.  The annual, semester long program is taught through physical education classes.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can’t contribute, don’t worry, but please help us spread the word by sharing this page with all your friends and family, and through your social media platforms!

Thank You
Thank you for making a donation to give kids an opportunity for happy, healthy, successful, and active futures!  

For more information: www.cyclekids.org or email: info@cyclekids.org 
Check out our photo and video gallery at the top of this page. 

An investment in one CYCLE Kids program will impact children and families in that school for 10 years or more.

story:
Short Summary

  • Hello! My name is Timothy Oyedele, I'm a 19 year old student from Houston, Texas the founder of The JuiceMan.
  • This campaign is intended to raise a portion of the initial costs to bring this business to fruition. The donations raised will go towards setting up a permanent location, obtaining local permits, and renovations.
  • This campaign means a lot to me because with your donations, we will help a lot of people take one step closer to a clean bill of health, one sip at a time!

What We Need & What You Get

  • I'm seeking to raise the first $7000 necessary to fund a permanent location, help pay for renovations, and obtain local and city permits.
  • Your good deeds will not go unrecognized!!! With every donation, donors will receive awesome gifts such as wristbands, water bottles, T-shirts, and other cool JuiceMan gear!
  • If the goal is not met, the raised funds will be used towards whatever is obtainable at the time. But regardless of how much is raised, any and all donations are greatly appreciated!

The Impact

  • Right now, the obesity rate is at an all time high, along with the chances of developing some form of cancer in one's lifetime. Organic fruits and vegetables have natural ailment preventing properties as well as other healthy benefits such as better moods, longer lasting energy, better metabolism, and an overall improvement of health.
  • The JuiceMan aims to put a dent into this epidemic through freshly pressed juices, smoothies, and health shots that help you take a step towards a healthier lifestyle without sacrificing taste.

Risks & Challenges

  • I, too, have struggled with weight loss problems in the past. Thanks to juice, exercise, and a proper diet, I was able to shed pounds more efficiently and keep the weight off. Also, I saw an improvement in my metabolism, energy, and overall attitude.
  • I do face quite a few obstacles through the duration of this project as would anyone starting a new business. But not only am I driven by my passion to succeed, I'm driven by my passion to truly help people who struggle with diet related health issues. And even if my goal isn't reached through this campaign, I will not stop until I make a positive impact against a negative issue in this country.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you are unable to donate at this time, that's perfectly fine :) You can still help by sharing this page through various social media networks to further spread the word about The JuiceMan and its mission to bring people closer to a clean bill of health, one sip at a time!

story:
Many people have heard me talk about how I have been growing my hair to donate for a 3rd time to Pantene® Beautiful Lengths. Pantene creates wigs for individuals affected by hair loss from cancer, and empowers them to walk through the world without a first impression defined by their illness. I am attempting to make an even greater impact, so I will also be making a small monetary donation and will be attempting to raise some money by the time I make the cut (one week from today, 7/21). Join me if you can (in hair, monetary, or any other way)!

For more information on Pantene Beautiful Lengths and how you can donate your hair, go here.

Stay tuned for pictures of my hair donation/cut.

story:
My name is Julio Letona, I'm the project development in charge of a Guatemalan NGO. For more than 5 years working in this project I realise that one of the most difficult things is to raise funds to make them. A volunteer recommended to me the 'crowfunding' platform, so here I am, very excited presenting our project  and hoping you can help us out to make it true. K'uxiub'al is an initiative to support the prevention and development project of Association for health and development (ASSADE), K'uxiub'al is a mayan term that means that we all put for the welfare of all. ASSADE is a guatemalan NGO located in the highlands, specifically in San Andrés Itzapa, Chimaltenango. A region with 33,000 inhabitants, where 90% belongs to the mayan ethnicity ‘kaqchikel’. Close to 75% of popolutation living in poverty, and near to 35% in extreme poverty, it means when people survive with less than a dollar per day and they don’t have access to cover the basic needs. ASSADE born with the dream of a women who worked 25 years in the public health system of Guatemala, during the civil war in the country that last for 36 years, in 1980; her brother, a doctor who she admired was murdered. After that moment, she noticed a lot of changes in the public health system, the transition to from dictatorship to democracy makes the health system will deploring, reaching ruin. In 2004 she decided to fund ASSADE, a non governmental and non profit organization, dedicated to promoting health and sustainable development, quality and social justice, especially in the maternal and child group living in poverty and extreme poverty. Her biggest dream is to built a entire health center to cover all people who need it, she wants to name the center after her brother, and she hopes not to die before seeing his dream come true.

ASSADE bases its actions on the belief that health care is a constitutive right of human beings and to address the psycho-social needs of individuals, families and communities. We understand development as the possibility that the different groups, ethnicities and cultures are free agents of their own destiny to economic, social and political level, with the ultimate aim the realization of women and men. ASSADE began as a only primary health clinic for two years, then it was possible to creat a very tiny pharmacy. Nowadays ASSADE has four clinics, two of them function in regular daily bases, one clinic to different purposes, once a month for example we have a day dedicated to the gynecological branch (pap testing, IUD method, ultrasounds, cryotherapy) or sometimes with volunteers of other specialties like physicology, physiotherapy, pediatrics, cardiology, among others. The other clinic will be for dental care, we still haven’t opened for resources but we hope in a near future it will be ready. ASSADE has a pharmacy, a recovery room, a warehouse, dining room and an office. We still pay rent for the facilities, because we have no resources to buy land and begin construction of the center. ASSADE is formed by a group of six people. ASSADE covers around 900 people monthly, people only pay a donation fee for consultation and meds according to their possibilities.

In 2011 we started working on prevention, that we believe is very important to cover and implement a project in the communities. We realise that is quite necessary to reach progress and human well being, through years we identified three prevailing conditions: respiratory problems, gastrointestinal problems and malnutrition. We looked for the real causes and started working on this, that’s how the prevention project was born. To explain what the project is about, we will share you a short story. 

We want you to meet Lesbia Micá, she is an indigenous women of the community in San Andrés Itzapa. She has 4 childrens, a 3 boys and a girl. She lives in small land property of her mother in law. As most of the families in the region, the family of Lesbia have access to water one hour every two days, unfortunately the water of the region isn’t drinkable, comes directly from the rivers with high levels of contamination. Her childs suffer from constant diarrhea and serious gastrointestinal infections (second cause of death in childrens under 7 years old in the region). She as an adult suffer less, but even so, at least three times a year she contracts an intestinal infection. 

Rivers in the región as used as a dump because the governamental service of waste disposal only covers 1% of the population, and the rest by private services, this only reach the 8% of population. One of the main reason of the low percentage is the cost. Lesbia’s husban is a farmer with an income of US$ 2 per day, so they used to cover the greatest need (food), as they live far from the river they get rid of the garbage burning it or throwing in the cesspool. First stage of the project, considering the evidence of the water problem in the region, ASSADE donated a water purifier to Lesbia’s family, also teach them how to use it and give it maintenance. Lesbia atended during two month once a week to receive trainings related to the water problem, related diseases, prevention mesuares, cycle of water, general hygiene, and environmental conservation. 

ASSADE works with group of women, that mean that first we stablished a group of women with the common needs, at the beginning women join with fear, but with the mental image of receiving a benefit, turns out that the guatemalan government bases its projects in giving away things. As the conditions of living of the women are precarious, they see that an alternative to cover they needs. It took a long time to change that mind, awareness of that kind of solutions only helps in a timely manner, but not a long term solution; or the solution isn’t based in the real problem, only cover the impact of that.  Then the groups start working as an alternative to introduced women to another environment beyond the rol of mother-wife, we realize that starting within our homes and our community there are differents problems involved, over time women notous that the group in itself have a whole meaning, an space of expression, an space of trust, of understanding, we think that every women at the group in differents moments reach the feeling of belonging, that is awesome, because all their lives they were taught that they only are to have childs and take care of their homes, that they don’t have a voice or right to choose in the macho culture, the group complete changes the ways to see life.

Lesbia also uses an open fire to cook, other risk for the health of her family, specially she and her childrens, that passed at least nine hours every day inside the room they used to cook. Places like this are linked to respiratory problems, also burns and burning eyes. Respiratory problems are the first cause of death in the region, specially in kids under seven years old. As one of the biggest problems, ASSADE helps to built a clean stoves, as a second stage of the project.

Open fire is more common way to cook in the región . At least 80% of the population use it. In first place because firewood is a fuel very easy to get, nowadays in the region there are no enviromental laws, so some families buy the firewood or dedicated working hours to get it. The smoke in the room is insupportable and the flames are a constant risk for Lesbia and her childrens. She only can cook one thing at the time. The space isn’t the ideal of hygiene. In Guatemala, 65% of deforestation due to the use for cooking. 

As a cohesive group, all the activities we carried out with a team work spirit. Her group mates help her throughout the process. Lesbia already received for two months training related to cook with open fire, linked diseases, ways of heat transfer, environmental conservation, cooking hygine, cultural significant of fire, how to confront the change of the way she cooks that will change all her life style. The new stove is portable, it is manufactured in the workshop so we can eliminated the old way of cooking and built the new one without waiting of drying process, and Lesbia can start using it until finish the construction. It uses three times less firewood, the fire chamber optimizes the fuel, is possible to cook two things at the same time, used the griddle to make ‘tortillas’, it has two wings to cover the absense of tables toe at in the families, it has a chimney driving 99% of smoke out side, also child protection. And it has a harmony with the mayan culture. 

The extreme poverty of families prevents them from eating full diets which meet even minimal nutritional standards. Only having access to meager amounts of the same food every day leads directly to malnutrition and stagnant development in children. In the region, that is base on agricultura, they grow corn and black beans, main ingredients of the regular diet in Guatemala. Food availability is one of the factors that influence the quantity and quality of the products consumed by a family. Children and women need a more varied diet. The immediate solution that we have implemented is alternative gardens and small raising hens farms, which work as an effective tool for the family to produce and consume low-cost, healthy food. In addition, the family is able to work together to produce food and future food security. This type of garden or farm and crop establishment is directly related to the needs and preferences of each family, always working as a group. At first, ASSADE works with groups of women, specially in training, in a wide range of training. From healt-related issues to ‘how to work in groups?’, covering communication skills, dispute resolution, gender violence, physcological and emotional issues, team work, a big variety of tools only to work in a group. Food availity is part of the third stage of the project, in other cases the group have chosen to make handicrafts and stablish a Little bussines, home hygiene products, this will depend on the group. The whole idea is the economical empowerment of women, transfering tools that they can be able to apply on their daily bases to reach a complete welfare of their family, group and community. 

Other important thing in the idea of creating and working a group, is the construction of alternatives for living as a women, recovery all the rights as a humans they deserve, and empowerment themselves. We confront the fact that one of the things that stop us from development is violence, also we teach and learn, we start as students and then become teachers, we always are learning. So, the groups exist as an space of expression and trust for women, to discuss around all the topics-problem that need to confront, in differents levels, space that allows them to recover their rights, practicing in their households and community, a group able to do political impact, inspired on protect and promote women beyond the alienating role, considering the environment, freedom, dignity and social peace to change lives, an space to share suffering. ASSADE created this idea of working with women groups, based that they can exist as a community union that can allow an alternative to look for progress and change lives, a sustainable long term alternative.

The education component of the project emphasizes the betterment of environment, health, and quality of life through grassroots knowledge. The education component is divided into two lines of action: The first line attempts to create economic stability for families. It establishes a business designed, organized and managed by the project participants. Decisions are made in group dialogue, avoiding inter-group complications. In addition, ASSADE guides them with the creation of the business and acts as an advisory board, which is especially important during the early stages of creation. The second line educates families in higher goals of autonomy and empowerment. It consists of workshops whose themes are chosen through discussion and by the members of the project (including both the participants and the ASSADE staff). On our part, we wish to address the issues which we believe are crippling rural life, as well as issues that arise in discussion. In particular, health issues and the importance of hand hygiene, dental hygiene and family planning, social and psychological issues such as self-esteem and gender violence, environmental preservation and economic issues such as the importance of saving are topics which are emphasized. These issues are proposed to the group in the same way which any other member may propose a topic that interests them. Both topics must be discussed and approved by the group before being carried out.

The dynamics of the trainings and workshops are also horizontal (they are run in a discussion, almost Socratic seminar, format). Keeping in mind that academic knowledge cannot replace empirical knowledge, the leaders of the discussion tread carefully with respect and openness. The training should form a harmonious workshop that transcends the myth of the dichotomy "wisdom" vs. "Ignorance". Because of this, we try to avoid teacher-student structure and the vertical transfer of academic content. The more formal content is discovered experientially through elements of reality in which we live.

The education component also sets real life, approachable role models and goals (for example, proposing solutions to improve their living conditions significantly). This methodology is based on the fact that cooperative relations within a group may in many cases meet such targets to improve living conditions.

We encourage group of women to take the tools that they have after time of training and lead it to the community, like other group of women, schools, and other groups. In the photo to the left, a training in a school of basic hygiene and how to avoid gastrointestinal deseases. At the end, we believe that the education component is the most important one in all the process. ASSADE doesn’t have any kind of support (national or internation), we only carried out this project with individual donations.

Since December 2011 we had worked with 52 families (238 persons) with this project, at this moment we are working with a new group of 30 women, where Lesbia belongs and we are facing the lack of resources to support final stages to complete the project.-

Why women? In the region, women have to face too many barriers, starting with three types of discrimination; as women, as indigenous, and as poor. Women are powerful, they only need the basic tools to create their own destiny. A beautiful, human and peaceful destination.-


What we need?

Details of funding

  • We will need to raise US$ 16,560 to change completly the life of 30 poor families in the region.
  • Break it down fund:  As the project is alredy running since November 2013, we are fundraising to cover to complete the project in March 2016
  • US$ 2,400 - Construction of saving stoves and make housing improvements to transform current kitchens into a safe and healthy place for 15 families. (15 families already have change it!!!).
  • US$ 460 - Implementation of 10 water ecological filters in 10 families in the region. (20 families already have a ecological water filter in their homes!!!).
  • US$ 3,000 - Food security Seed Capital - for all the group of 30 families. They will work as a cooperative to stablish family gardens and bredding hens in the community, as the beginning to ensure complete feeding of 50 children under twelve years of the community, in a long-term solution.
  • US$ 3,800 - Food support during 6 months for 30 families in community. As the cooperative take at least 6 months to start sustainability, we make sure that families have access to primary daily food and make sure that the resources of the food security seed capital worth. Also, this funds will be use it to recover the nutriotional status of 50% of the kids of the group that suffer from some form of malnutrition (acute and severe).  
  • US$ 1,500 - Weekly four-hour educational workshops, technical assistance and field for seed capital utilization, implementation and sustainability, during 3 months.
  • US$ 3,000 - Supporting workshops for kids in the village so they can expand their minds, the public education in the country isn't enough, An space of trust, learning, beyond what exists, a place the childs can be individuals for transformation. Workshops in art, literature and sports. Different workshops working in a regular basis in the community, as well as a small library. Dental care for childrens and womem.
  • US$ 1900 - Monitoring and Evaluation: Medical and field. All the kids are monitored and evaluated by doctors to see the progress, also in field to make sure that the impact of the project is reaching the objectives. 
  • US$ 500 - Administrative and operating expenses for project management
  • Note: ASSADE will support most of the administrative and operating expenses, also the planning, logistics and implementations of the actions. Near to US$ 8,000 counterpart to end this unique and succesfully project. 

Impact

What we will get with the funds:

  • The lives of 50 childrens and 30 women, of a 100% poor and indigenous community, will change for better.
  • Stop the suffering of gastrointestinal and respiratory problems in childrens and womens, first causes of death in the region. 
  • Recovery of general health on children and women of the community.
  • Promote preventive health in the community.
  • Women empowerment - Women can have access to tools and knoweledge to transform their lives and their childrens with their own means. 
  • Reduction of malnutrition conditions of the 50 childrens and the construction of a road to reach the food security in a long term.
  • Give the chance to families to stablish a healthy economy at their homes, allowing them to cover other important aspects in their lifes; like giving to the childs the right to go to school. Nowadays only 40% of childrens go to the school, in Guatemala it supposed that education is free, in theory only, turns out that is a expense that many families can't allow.
  • Open a space of expression, learning and peaceful for kids in the community, a space where they can find so many valuable tools and improve their lifes.
  • Reducing poverty permanently these families through education and teamwork, throug community union, as our campaing's name says, through K'uxiub'al - the impact of our actions will be definitely, it means that is only one time investment-.

Risks and challenges

Maybe the biggest risks and challenges of the project are male violence, survival and mental image in the women caused by government projects, of give palliatives to try to solve serious problems, that at the end only maintains the situation as it is, we want to make serious changes, better and trutly changes.

  • We focus in the real causes of the problems. We confron the problems from a integral perspective, including the community and professionals.
  • Our gratest weapon to confront risks and challenges is education. We believe in education for transformation. Our impacts in the past have confirmed that it is actually a outstanding key to the project.
  • Monitoring and evaluating process it's fundamental for us, we keep tracking the progress in a long term. 
If we don't raise completly the funds, we will prioritize on education, nutrition, water purifieres and transformation the areas dedicated to cooking in the region. At the end, imagine that with a little more than US$500 you can change completly a life of a whole family in the highlands of Guatemala. Please, in behalf of ASSADE and all these families, consider to help us. Every penny make a difference. Remember, K'UXIUB'AL, all for the welfare of all, .-

Other ways to help...

You also can help us to support the project in different ways.

  • You can help sharing information in your circles of friends, coworkers, family, gym, school, church or college. As we don’t have a complex system of fundraising we need people to help us to spread the word. You can request more information of our actividades sending a email to: assadeguate@gmail.com

IF YOU WANT TO SEE A LITTLE MORE YOU CAN GO TO LABEL "GALLERY" TO SEE SPECIFIC VIDEOS AND PHOTOS OF THE PROJECT. PLEASE, TAKE A FEW MORE MINUTES.

Thank you - Matyox - Gracias - Thank you - Matyox - Gracias - Thank you - Matyox
story_txt:
My name is Julio Letona, I'm the project development in charge of a Guatemalan NGO. For more than 5 years working in this project I realise that one of the most difficult things is to raise funds to make them. A volunteer recommended to me the 'crowfunding' platform, so here I am, very excited presenting our project  and hoping you can help us out to make it true. K'uxiub'al is an initiative to support the prevention and development project of Association for health and development (ASSADE), K'uxiub'al is a mayan term that means that we all put for the welfare of all. ASSADE is a guatemalan
NGO located in the highlands, specifically in San Andrés Itzapa, Chimaltenango.
A region with 33,000 inhabitants, where 90% belongs to the mayan ethnicity
‘kaqchikel’. Close to 75% of popolutation living in poverty, and near to 35% in
extreme poverty, it means when people survive with less than a dollar per day
and they don’t have access to cover the basic needs. ASSADE born with the dream
of a women who worked 25 years in the public health system of Guatemala, during
the civil war in the country that last for 36 years, in 1980; her brother, a
doctor who she admired was murdered. After that moment, she
noticed a lot of changes in the public health system, the transition to from
dictatorship to democracy makes the health system will deploring, reaching ruin.
In 2004 she decided to fund ASSADE, a non governmental and non profit
organization, dedicated to promoting health and sustainable development,
quality and social justice, especially in the maternal and child group living
in poverty and extreme poverty. Her biggest dream is to built a entire health
center to cover all people who need it, she wants to name the center after her
brother, and she hopes not to die before seeing his dream come true.

ASSADE bases its actions on
the belief that health care is a constitutive right of human beings and to
address the psycho-social needs of individuals, families and communities. We
understand development as the possibility that the different groups,
ethnicities and cultures are free agents of their own destiny to economic,
social and political level, with the ultimate aim the realization of women and
men. ASSADE began as a only primary health clinic for two years, then it was possible
to creat a very tiny pharmacy. Nowadays ASSADE has four clinics, two of them
function in regular daily bases, one clinic to different purposes, once a month
for example we have a day dedicated to the gynecological branch (pap testing,
IUD method, ultrasounds, cryotherapy) or sometimes with volunteers of other
specialties like physicology, physiotherapy, pediatrics, cardiology, among
others. The other clinic will be for dental care, we still haven’t opened for
resources but we hope in a near future it will be ready. ASSADE has a pharmacy,
a recovery room, a warehouse, dining room and an office. We still pay rent for
the facilities, because we have no resources to buy land and begin construction
of the center. ASSADE is formed by a group of six people. ASSADE covers around
900 people monthly, people only pay a donation fee for consultation and meds
according to their possibilities. 
In 2011 we started working on
prevention, that we believe is very important to cover and implement a project
in the communities. We realise that is quite necessary to reach progress and
human well being, through years we identified three prevailing conditions:
respiratory problems, gastrointestinal problems and malnutrition. We looked for
the real causes and started working on this, that’s how the prevention project
was born. To explain what the project is about, we will share you a short
story. 

We want you to meet Lesbia
Micá, she is an indigenous women of the community in San Andrés Itzapa. She has 4
childrens, a 3 boys and a girl. She lives in small land property of her mother
in law. As most of the families in the region,
the family of Lesbia have access to water one hour every two days, unfortunately
the water of the region isn’t drinkable, comes directly from the rivers with
high levels of contamination. Her childs suffer from constant diarrhea and
serious gastrointestinal infections (second cause of death in childrens under 7
years old in the region). She as an adult suffer less, but even so, at least
three times a year she contracts an intestinal infection. 


Rivers in the región as
used as a dump because the governamental service of waste disposal only covers
1% of the population, and the rest by private services, this only reach the 8%
of population. One of the main reason of the low percentage is the cost.
Lesbia’s husban is a farmer with an income of US$ 2 per day, so they used to
cover the greatest need (food), as they live far from the river they get rid of
the garbage burning it or throwing in the cesspool. First stage of the project,
considering the evidence of the water problem in the region, ASSADE donated a
water purifier to Lesbia’s family, also teach them how to use it and give it
maintenance. Lesbia atended during two month once a week to receive trainings
related to the water problem, related diseases, prevention mesuares, cycle of
water, general hygiene, and environmental conservation. 



ASSADE
works with group of women, that mean that first we stablished a group of women
with the common needs, at the beginning women join with fear, but with the
mental image of receiving a benefit, turns out that the guatemalan government
bases its projects in giving away things. As the conditions of living of the
women are precarious, they see that an alternative to cover they needs. It took
a long time to change that mind, awareness of that kind of solutions only helps
in a timely manner, but not a long term solution; or the solution isn’t based
in the real problem, only cover the impact of that.  Then the groups start working as an
alternative to introduced women to another environment beyond the rol of
mother-wife, we realize that starting within our homes and our community there
are differents problems involved, over time women notous that the group in
itself have a whole meaning, an space of expression, an space of trust, of
understanding, we think that every women at the group in differents moments
reach the feeling of belonging, that is awesome, because all their lives they
were taught that they only are to have childs and take care of their homes,
that they don’t have a voice or right to choose in the macho culture, the group
complete changes the ways to see life.
Lesbia
also uses an open fire to cook, other risk for the health of her family,
specially she and her childrens, that passed at least nine hours every day
inside the room they used to cook. Places like this are linked to respiratory
problems, also burns and burning eyes. Respiratory problems are the first cause
of death in the region, specially in kids under seven years old. As one of the
biggest problems, ASSADE helps to built a clean stoves, as a second stage of the project.

Open fire is more common way to cook in the región . At least 80% of the population use it. In first place because
firewood is a fuel very easy to get, nowadays in the region there are no enviromental
laws, so some families buy the firewood or dedicated working hours to get it. The smoke in the room is insupportable and the flames are a
constant risk for Lesbia and her childrens. She only can cook one thing at the
time. The space isn’t the ideal of hygiene. In Guatemala, 65% of deforestation due to the use for
cooking. 




As a cohesive
group, all the activities we carried out with a team work spirit. Her group mates help her throughout the process. Lesbia already received for two months training related to cook
with open fire, linked diseases, ways of heat transfer, environmental
conservation, cooking hygine, cultural significant of fire, how to confront the
change of the way she cooks that will change all her life style. The new stove is
portable, it is manufactured in the workshop so we can eliminated the old way
of cooking and built the new one without waiting of drying process, and Lesbia
can start using it until finish the construction. It uses three times less
firewood, the fire chamber optimizes the fuel, is possible to cook two things
at the same time, used the griddle to make ‘tortillas’, it has two wings to
cover the absense of tables toe at in the families, it has a chimney driving
99% of smoke out side, also child protection. And it has a harmony with the
mayan culture. 
The
extreme poverty of families prevents them from eating full diets which meet
even minimal nutritional standards. Only having access to meager amounts of the
same food every day leads directly to malnutrition and stagnant development in
children. In the region, that is base on agricultura, they grow corn and black
beans, main ingredients of the regular diet in Guatemala. Food availability is
one of the factors that influence the quantity and quality of the products
consumed by a family. Children and women need a more varied diet. The immediate
solution that we have implemented is alternative gardens and small raising hens
farms, which work as an effective tool for the family to produce and consume
low-cost, healthy food. In addition, the family is able to work together to
produce food and future food security. This type of garden or farm and crop
establishment is directly related to the needs and preferences of each family,
always working as a group. At first, ASSADE works with groups of women,
specially in training, in a wide range of training. From healt-related issues
to ‘how to work in groups?’, covering communication skills, dispute resolution,
gender violence, physcological and emotional issues, team work, a big variety
of tools only to work in a group. Food availity is part of the third stage of
the project, in other cases the group have chosen to make handicrafts and
stablish a Little bussines, home hygiene products, this will depend on the
group. The whole idea is the economical empowerment of women, transfering tools
that they can be able to apply on their daily bases to reach a complete welfare
of their family, group and community. 

Other important thing in the
idea of creating and working a group, is the construction of alternatives for
living as a women, recovery all the rights as a humans they deserve, and
empowerment themselves. We confront the fact that one of the things that stop
us from development is violence, also we teach and learn, we start as students
and then become teachers, we always are learning. So, the groups exist as an
space of expression and trust for women, to discuss around all the
topics-problem that need to confront, in differents levels, space that allows
them to recover their rights, practicing in their households and community, a
group able to do political impact, inspired on protect and promote women beyond
the alienating role, considering the environment, freedom, dignity and social
peace to change lives, an space to share suffering. ASSADE created this idea of
working with women groups, based that they can exist as a community union that
can allow an alternative to look for progress and change lives, a sustainable
long term alternative.The
education component of the project emphasizes the betterment of environment,
health, and quality of life through grassroots knowledge. The education
component is divided into two lines of action: The
first line attempts to create economic stability for families. It establishes a
business designed, organized and managed by the project participants. Decisions
are made in group dialogue, avoiding inter-group complications. In addition,
ASSADE guides them with the creation of the business and acts as an advisory
board, which is especially important during the early stages of creation. The
second line educates families in higher goals of autonomy and empowerment. It
consists of workshops whose themes are chosen through discussion and by the
members of the project (including both the participants and the ASSADE staff).
On our part, we wish to address the issues which we believe are crippling rural
life, as well as issues that arise in discussion. In particular, health issues
and the importance of hand hygiene, dental hygiene and family planning, social
and psychological issues such as self-esteem and gender violence, environmental
preservation and economic issues such as the importance of saving are topics
which are emphasized. These issues are proposed to the group in the same way
which any other member may propose a topic that interests them. Both topics
must be discussed and approved by the group before being carried out.
The dynamics of the trainings
and workshops are also horizontal (they are run in a discussion, almost
Socratic seminar, format). Keeping in mind that academic knowledge cannot
replace empirical knowledge, the leaders of the discussion tread carefully with
respect and openness. The training should form a harmonious workshop that
transcends the myth of the dichotomy "wisdom" vs.
"Ignorance". Because of this, we try to avoid teacher-student
structure and the vertical transfer of academic content. The more formal content

significantly). This methodology is based on the fact that cooperative
relations within a group may in many cases meet such targets to improve living
conditions.

We encourage group of
women to take the tools that they have after time of training and lead it to
the community, like other group of women, schools, and other groups. In the
photo to the left, a training in a school of basic hygiene and how to avoid
gastrointestinal deseases. At the end, we believe that the education component
is the most important one in all the process. ASSADE doesn’t have any kind of

individual donations. 
Since December 2011 we had worked with 52 families (238 persons)

(15 families already have change it!!!).

US$ 3,000 - Food security Seed Capital - for all the group of 30 families. They will work as a cooperative to stablish family gardens and bredding hens in the community, as the beginning to ensure complete feeding of 50 children under twelve years of the community, in a long-term solution.
US$ 3,800 - Food support during 6 months for 30 families in community. As the cooperative take at least 6 months to start sustainability, we make sure that families have access to primary daily food and make sure that the resources of the food security seed capital worth. Also, this funds will be use it to recover the nutriotional status of 50% of the kids of the group that suffer from some form of malnutrition (acute and severe).  
US$ 1,500 - Weekly four-hour educational workshops, technical assistance and field for seed capital utilization, implementation and sustainability, during 3 months.

story:
Our Story

My name is Dr. Milton O'Brien, a chiropractor in San Francisco practicing bio-mechanics for over 30 years. ​​My mother Joyce ​ suffered a massive stroke paralyzing her completely on her right side when she ​was 89 years old.  After she came home from the hospital trying to move her from one place to another became extremely difficult.  That's when I got the idea to create TransferPants™.

TransferPants™ have handles sewn into the outside of the pants and into the liner.  TransferPants™ worked so well and are so unique that it was eligible to receive a U.S. patent.   

Why are we making TransferPants™?


There are​ over 4 million people today living in wheelchairs in the U.S. alone​ NOT​ counting those who are partially​ paralyzed​. People ​with​ brain injuries, spinal cord injuries, strokes, heart attack, birth defects, and disable​d​ vets.

We’ve been selling TransferPants™ since January 2015, and buyers responses have been overwhelmingly positive. Most buyers start by purchasing one pair of TransferPants™ and within a few weeks come back for more, Emailing us testimonials about how well TransferPants™ work, and how they have improved the lives of their loved ones and their caregivers.

We have created our new line of TransferPants™ that we have improved on over  the last 12 months. We have added 2 zippers in the front  for easy dressing, new styles, softer materials, and  more colors.


TransferPants™ Solutions:


  • Prevents falls and serious injuries
  • Inconspicuous and unobtrusive handles put less strain on the back of the caregiver
  • Interior liner prevents an uncomfortable “wedgie”
  • Security for the individual during rehabilitation, physical therapy and activities of daily living
  • Ideal for mobility challenged individuals with lower extremity weakness and paralysis
  • Skin abrasions and discomfort are less likely
  • Machine-washable


How it works



Styles, Colors and Sizes


Gray Fleece

   

Everyday wear, comfortable and warm with soft feel.

Black Fleece


Everyday wear, comfortable and warm with soft feel.


Olive Cotton Twill


Casual everyday wear, cool and comfortable fit.


Khaki Cotton Twill

Casual everyday wear, cool and comfortable fit.


Black Cotton Twill

Casual everyday wear, cool and comfortable fit.


Cargo Shorts

Casual everyday wear, cool and comfortable fit, perfect for picnics and barbecues.


Bathing Suit

 

For showering and bathing, rehab or a day at the pool.

Black Baggies

For a more formal setting, without compromising fit and comfort.


Original Black Pants, Fleece or Denim, no zippers

Our original everyday wear.


What We Need & What You Get

We are currently seeking $20,000 in funding in order to create our new line of TransferPants™ that we have improved on over the last 12 months. We have added 2 zippers in the front  for easy dressing, new styles, softer materials, and more colors. 

By funding this Indiegogo Campaign,  you are going to have a positive impact on the lives of your relatives, your friends, and even people you don’t know who are mobility challenged in the U.S. and the entire planet. It’s a great thing to do and we need your support to get this job done and help those who have trouble helping themselves.


Other Ways You Can Help

Any pledge is greatly appreciated, but we also encourage you to help us spread the word about our campaign to as many people as possible! Share our link by email, on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram. 


FAQ:

Where Does the Money Go?

The $20,000 goal will allow us to produce our first run of the styles we are offering. The funding will go to purchasing TransferPants™, manufacturing costs, and distribution of this premium quality products. 

Any funds above and beyond our goal will allow us to take this project and turn it into a real company focused on producing quality garments for disabled people. We'll be able to offer more styles, more colors, and in more places! 


How Do They Fit?

We understand that not everyone's bodies is shaped the same.

  • TransferPants™ is designed for both men and women (unisex).
  • Account for room in the waist, hip, thighs, knees, and calves, including undergarments (diapers).
  • It is important to look at the waist measurements first, to match your size correctly. 
  • The size chart below corresponds to all of these measurements.
  • Children's sizes are coming soon.


How long would it take to get my products?

Since we are working with top quality manufacturers and because all our products are hand made by artisans who put a lot of effort to their work, manufacturing takes more time than regular mass production. For that reason, we estimate shipping:

  • Perks - by April 2016
  • All other inventory - by August 2016




What if they don't fit?
Make sure you've checked the size chart above on fit and sizing, and ask any questions you might have before selecting a size for yourself.

If you feel these do not fit you we can exchange them for a different size. No problem.

What if I buy them as a gift and I can't take the recipient's measurements?
No problem. Put a note in the comments section that it is a gift. We will send a gift card to the receiver and ask for their measurements.

TransferPants™ Solutions:




Prevents falls and serious injuries

Inconspicuous and unobtrusive handles put less strain on the back of the caregiver

Interior liner prevents an uncomfortable “wedgie”
Security for the individual during rehabilitation, physical therapy and activities of daily living
Ideal for mobility challenged individuals with lower extremity weakness and paralysis
Skin abrasions and discomfort are less likely
Machine-washable
 


How it works




Styles, Colors and Sizes




Gray Fleece

   
Everyday wear, comfortable and warm with soft feel.



Black Fleece

   


Everyday wear, comfortable and warm with soft feel.


Olive Cotton Twill

    Casual everyday wear, cool and comfortable fit.

Khaki Cotton Twill

   
Casual everyday wear, cool and comfortable fit.


Black Cotton Twill

   
Casual everyday wear, cool and comfortable fit.


Cargo Shorts

   
Casual everyday wear, cool and comfortable fit, perfect for picnics and barbecues.








Bathing Suit

  
For showering and bathing, rehab or a day at the pool.Black Baggies
 

For a more formal setting, without compromising fit and comfort.


Original Black Pants, Fleece or Denim, no zippers



Our original everyday wear.


  What We Need & What You Get

We are currently seeking $20,000 in funding in order to create our new line of TransferPants™ that we have improved on over the last 12 months. We have added 2 zippers in the front  for easy dressing, new styles, softer materials, and more colors. 
By funding this Indiegogo Campaign,  you are going to have a positive impact on the lives of your relatives, your friends, and even people you don’t know who are mobility challenged in the U.S. and the entire planet. It’s a great thing to do and we need your support to get this job done and help those who have trouble helping themselves.




    Other Ways You Can Help
Any pledge is greatly appreciated, but we also encourage you to help us spread the word about our campaign to as many people as possible! Share our link by email, on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram. 


FAQ:

Where Does the Money Go?


The $20,000 goal will allow us to produce our first run of the styles we are offering. The funding will go to purchasing TransferPants™, manufacturing costs, and distribution of this premium quality products. 
Any funds above and beyond our goal will allow us to take this project and turn it into a real company focused on producing quality garments for disabled people. We'll be able to offer more styles, more colors, and in more places! 
How Do They Fit?
We understand that not everyone's bodies is shaped the same.

TransferPants™ is designed for both men and women (unisex).
Account for room in the waist, hip, thighs, knees, and calves, including undergarments (diapers).
It is important to look at the waist measurements first, to match your size correctly. 

The size chart below corresponds to all of these measurements.
Children's sizes are coming soon.









How long would it take to get my products?
Since we are working with top quality manufacturers and because all our products are hand made by artisans who put a lot of effort to their work, manufacturing takes more time than regular mass production. For that reason, we estimate shipping:



Perks - by April 2016

All other inventory - by August 2016










What if they don't fit?Make sure you've checked the size chart above on fit and sizing, and ask any questions you might have before selecting a size for yourself.If you feel these do not fit you we can exchange them for a different size. No problem.What if I buy them as a gift and I can't take the recipient's measurements?No problem. Put a note in the comments section that it is a gift. We will send a gift card to the receiver and ask for their measurements.

story:
All funds will be going towards living expenses, medical costs including technologies required to monitor as well as to administer, the medications needed and treatment.

I am a friend, trying to help a friend, and I know there are more people out there that are willing to help, even strangers from across the country and globe -- it is much appreciated and welcomed.

This is a sixty day campaign!

Let's make it count!

Average monthly costs using an insulin pump with sensor consist of but is not limited to the testing kits costing $110, sensors costs $250, insertion sets $180 on a monthly basis not including other costs! 

  • The average cost of an Insulin Pump Cost is $7,000

The annual cost of living with Diabetes in Canada is estimated at $7,200 and is not inclusive on time taken off work and that loss of income. which we are also trying to help alleviate the stresses of, for Jeff.

  • All funds will be placed in Trust for Jeff Maxwell, giving the amount of donations received, medical equipment and supplies will be purchased in bulk to receive better prices as when able, rent will be paid in advance, again, giving consideration of the amount that is donated.
  • Whether we are able to raise, or you are able to donate more than even the smallest dollar amount, I, myself, would be proud that people came together to show support from a fellow community member or complete stranger.

story:
Short Summary

Poor health is pushing 39 million Indians to poverty every year; Rural India needs 19,236 specialists at its community health centers but it has a shortfall of 12,310 doctors; About 30% of people in rural India did not opt for treatment because of financial constraints; 31 percent of the rural population in India has to travel over 30 km to get needed medical treatment; 8% of the Primary Healthcare Centers  do not have doctors or medical staff; 50 percent of obstetricians, pediatricians, and gynecologists positions are vacant.

PRADAN (www.pradan.net) is a public service organization registered under society act, headquartered in Delhi. PRADAN has been working in 42 districts in 8 states across India towards poverty alleviation in remote tribal regions of the country. It has been working since 1983 in hinterland of central India with a mission of impacting livelihood to enable rural community. By March 2015, PRADAN worked with over 380,000 families in 5,429 villages in 104 blocks spread over 42 districts across the States of Assam, Bihar, Chhattisgarh, Jharkhand, Madhya Pradesh, Orissa, Rajasthan and West Bengal. 

A successful pilot was undertaken from June to August 2015 in 9 villages of Dholpur (www.dholpur.rajasthan.gov.in), one of the most backward and challenging region of India to provide Health Services using Mobile Technologies to the families through local cadre commonly known as Jan Sakhi. It is now planned to scale this to over 100 villages to be able to provide health services to over 30,000 families on cost sharing basis.

What We Need

The Mobile Health Scale-up Program needs USD 300,000 for every 100 villages and will cover expenses spanning Healthcare Delivery, Technology, Human Resources and Operations over a 5 year period. 

The program has been designed in a way that the end users will start contributing from the fourth year to make it self-sustainable in the long term.

The Impact

The  program will make healthcare accessible, affordable and accurate for the sections of the society that have long been deprived of primary health services. 
Through a coordinated orchestration of Healthcare Delivery, Technology, Human Resources and Operations, the program will create a triage model utilizing front-line workers with low education levels but high enthusiasm, to alleviate the acute shortfall of trained medical professionals, particularly in difficult habitats. 
Besides primary health, the goal is also to address locally-significant issues like Silicosis, Tuberculosis, Maternal Mortality Rate, Infant Mortality Rate and Immunization.

Other Ways You Can Help

For people with bank account in India, you can also contribute in the following ways mentioning 'Jan Sakhi' in your remittance:

(a) Electronic Transfer to 'Saheli Samiti, Dholpur'; Account Number: 1942000100909995; Punjab National Bank (IFSC: PUNB0194200).

(b) Mail a Cheque or Demand Draft favoring 'Saheli Samiti, Dholpur' to Saheli, 1/363, Anand Nagar, Saipau Road, Dholpur, 328001 (Rajasthan).

Contributions qualify for deduction under Section 80G of Indian Income Tax Act. KYC documents will be required for amounts greater than INR 50,000.
