He is a clear example of how discipline, dedication, and hard work can help you climb the ladder and be successful in a company.
He expects this project to meet all he has ever envisioned, especially since it involves not only a great contribution to the community but also one of his greatest passions, sports. He is certain that his partners and he have all the qualities that make an entrepreneur succeed. Thus, this will be a great part of his professional and personal growth.
Daniel Ampuero
Daniel Ampuero is a Senior Industrial and Systems Engineer at Texas A&M University with entrepreneurial passion, who holds integrity as one of his key qualities and who takes on everyday life with optimism and creativity. As an Industrial Engineer, he has participated in internships with Rolls Royce (USA), Toyota (USA), Allinton Engineering & Trading PTE LTD (Singapore). Aside from his studies, together with college friends he co-founded a service organization (S.T.A.R.T TAMU) and is very involved with soccer leagues in the College Station area (BCS league and TAMU intramurals). He is looking to graduate in Spring 2017 and continue to pursue his entrepreneurial and personal endeavors diligently.
Gustavo Tapia
Gustavo Tapia is a PhD candidate in Industrial Engineering at Texas A&M, with a BS in Mechanical Engineering. His entrepreneurial mindset shared with passion for sports, especially soccer, were the influential factors for him to venture into this project.
He has participated in several soccer leagues at various competition levels, and thanks to his leadership skills have brought people and friends together to form teams and served as captain. For this reason, he has been around many people that share the same enthusiasm for soccer, and understands their needs in order for them to get the best soccer experience.
Gustavo is confident that this venture will start off successfully given the capable team that is behind it, working hard everyday to bring HTX Sports Creek to live to the Houston community.



   What We Need & What You Get
We need to raise $30,000 to help us build our a state of the art sports facility. We will build a 7 v 7 turf soccer field, two sand volleyball courts and a hangout place where our customers can enjoy food and beer. 
With the money that we raise, we will also offer 3, $1,000 college scholarships to outstanding athletes at the end of each school year.
 Our mission is to provide a superior experience through different services that promote a healthy lifestyle.
    Our Facility






Sports
Creek is an outdoor soccer and sand volleyball facility that will be lit with SOLAR ENERGY. The venue will offer league
and tournament play, private soccer training, boot camps and a snack bar to
enjoy both beer and food.  The facility will also be available to be
rented out for special events.   
The following is the fee
schedule:
· 
Annual Facility
Membership: $40
· 
Soccer Team
Registration per Session: $700 ($500 the first two sessions)
· 
Sand Volleyball Team
Registration: $250
· 
Boot Camp Fee: $45
(per month)
· 
Facility Rental Fee:
Member $55 - 65/hr, Non-Member $80/hr
· 
Skill Clinic Fees:
Range from $45 (per hour) for children, to $400 for groups
Private coaching will be
led by soccer-skill instructors with "A" Level Coaching
Certification.  The skill clinics will be geared towards the novice who wishes
to improve upon their skill set. 
 We will also have a snack bar which
will sell delicious sandwiches, snacks, drinks and beer from a local brewery. 

    Other Ways You Can Help If you can't financially help us, you can just share our link on facebook to spread the word about us. This is a new project and environment in Houston and we want all the community to know about it and help us out.

story:
The Head Over Heels Story

My name is Jessica Edwards. I live in Polson, Montana, a small town on the Flathead Reservation with about 5,000 year-round residents. I started teaching gymnastics here about six years ago and have had a wildly enthusiastic response from the community. I'm the big one in this photo taken back then.

I started teaching 24 years ago when I was 16, to pay for my own classes. I was driving to Kalispell all the time because the closest gymnastics facilities are 60 miles north or south of Polson. Because of this I have students from numerous other small towns in the Mission Valley. Some kids are built for gymnastics or dance, and I love providing a place for them to discover their talents. For other kids gymnastics training develops in them coordination, strength, flexibility and confidence that will help them excel in other sports and through all of life. We have winter for a good six months here, and I value hospitality - providing a warm, dry place for physical activity and community recreation when there's not a whole lot else available! I named my business Head Over Heels, LLC, and we've been using a church fellowship hall - my husband and four kids helping me set up and take down equipment each week (This is an old picture - they are harder workers now!).

Now we are finally getting our own leased facility, built to suit! Everyone in town seems to be talking about the new gym, which is supposed to be ready for action in September!

I've found awesome deals on used equipment, driven (or sent my husband to drive!) to haul it back, and filled up storage units with these treasures until we can get into the gym. 

I've also found awesome staff - energetic, creative, talented and compassionate athletes who are developing gymnastics and dance skills in their students while simultaneously developing character in them for whole-life health! These are the real treasures. 

In order to keep my prices for students accessible and be able to pay my staff adequately I am trying to raise money to purchase the last few major pieces of equipment for the new gym.  

What We Need 

Through generous gifts from local businesses and individuals, our year-end show and chili feed/silent auction raised just over $3500 towards the spring floor for the new gym. I needed another $3,500 for the floor, but when I asked my brother to review the campaign before I launched it he gave us our first donation - $1000! He gets the first Private Pit Party, and that lowers our need for the floor to $2500! (I have the carpet bonded foam,  but we need springs, baltic birch plywood, velcro, adhesives and hardware):

We need about $9,000 for the foam pit (including the various parts you see in the illustration below, and shipping):

We will also need a pit bar, with a price tag of somewhere around $3500 (I don't have this piece selected yet which is why I don't know more precisely. I think that the price I listed will cover it.) Here's one option:

That puts my total need at $15,000 (it was $16,000 before I showed it to George). I've purchased much of my other equipment used or new at great prices, so I have two balance beams, one set of uneven bars, one vault, the top half of the floor and lots of base mats as well as training tools and preschool equipment already, which have cost me about $24,000 to date. I also have two balance beams that were purchased for Head Over Heels with a gift from the board members of Polson Running! 
I will spend the first donations from this campaign on the spring floor. Next I will work on setting up the pit and then filling it. If we don't raise the full amount then I will work on finishing up the projects as I have money after paying the lease and making payroll and utilities each month. If we raise more than the full amount, or if I get a great discount on something and have left over money I will spend it on mirrors, a trampoline, or a climbing wall over the pit!!! I've selected an option that makes it so you can continue to give even after the campaign ends. If you would prefer to give me cash or a check in person I will certainly still honor the perks - and it will save us the 5% fee that is taken out by this hosting site. I think you could also give via your Jackrabbit account if you'd like.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you have no money (or want to help in additional ways):
    • Share this campaign with your rich relatives (or even just generous grandparents!). Use the Indiegogo sharing tools at the top of the page.
    • Volunteer your time to help move and set up the gym once it's ready for us to move in (the whole family can help with parts of this!).
    • Volunteer your time and carpentry talent to help with the finishing touches to make the gym a hospitable space. 
    • Can you sew? I have a big sewing project for the gym, and many hands make light work! I also need one mastermind who can head up the sewing project, so if you're willing to consider that job, give me an email or a call.
    • My contact information is headoverheelsmontana@gmail.com or 406-270-9824. Please let me know how you can help.
    • You can pray for us. Pray that we have the funding we need for equipment and operations. Pray for safety for students and staff. Pray that our students would grow in wisdom, in stature, and in favor with God and man. Thank you!!!

    Why is Head Over Heels not a non-profit?

    I've been asked that question frequently, and I've strongly considered the possibility, but I've settled on being a small business instead. As we work toward this expansion Head Over Heels certainly is not turning a profit. I hope it will end up being a sustainable business long-term, though the community will have to grow in population before the gym could be truly profitable. My reason for not becoming a 501(c)3 organization is not financial. It comes down to my desire to be hospitable to the community in big variety of ways. If I were selecting a board of directors I can think of many people who share one part of my vision, but it would be hard to find anyone who shares the whole of my vision. I want the freedom to be spontaneously hospitable, and I'd like to bless the community with another healthy business as well. It'll be a while, maybe, but I think it will come.

story:
They said it could never be done!

99% pure oxygen, human beings most valuable element, in a disposable and simple easy to use device at a price that defies logic?   Well LifefloTM did it and here is how. Lifeflo OTC emergency Oxygen is based on breakthrough technologies allow us to manufacture efficiently, cost effectively and provide the simplest, most affordable oxygen delivery device available.  It has no electronics, no high pressure cylinders, no complicated regulators and no maintenance requirements.   Once you are done using it - you simply discard it.   

Providing oxygen to someone injured or distressed while waiting for EMS services to arrive can make a positive difference in survival (mortality) and long term effects of injury (morbidity).  We never expect accidents to occur but inevitably they will, either directly or indirectly, impact you.  Like fire extinguishers, Epipens, smoke alarms and automatic external defibrillators (AEDs) having a LifefloTM OTC Emergency Oxygen device available during a medical emergency could dramatically change your or loved ones future.

Another very important reason for developing this technology is providing oxygen to those less fortunate that do not have such a basic medical intervention readily available.  

We will keep this very high level but you need some background on the science of oxygenation and why you need it.  Oxygen is the miraculous element that permits life to exist and flourish on earth.  It is a simple and indisputable fact – oxygen is necessary to sustain life.  Clinical studies show that a human being can live for days without water, and weeks without food – but without Oxygen biological DEATH begins to occur within 3 MINUTES.  

The body’s ability to deliver critical oxygen to vital organs during an emergency can be compromised 2 ways – circulatory (blood flow) and respiratory (air flow) or both.  Circulatory events might be due to heart attack, stroke, trauma, severe blood loss or electrical shock to name a few.  Respiratory events might include asthma, COPD, choking, drowning or paralysis as examples.  Every medical emergency can potentially benefit from the delivery of oxygen.

In the United States alone there are over 120 million 911 calls per year resulting in 12 million emergency room visits.  In at a vast majority of those oxygen is provided by EMS or first responders.  With the average emergency service response time being 12-15 minutes nationwide it would only make sense to make oxygen available wherever and whenever it is needed - in your home or workplace.  Is this a new concept? No.  What is new is that LifefloTM makes it affordable at $.08 per day!  A retail price of $89.99 and a shelf life of 3 years equals $.08 per day.

There is a little known category that the FDA allows for Oxygen, in it’s pure medical grade form, to be sold direct to consumers for emergency use – without a prescription.  It does not exempt us from the comprehensive FDA guidelines regarding safety and usage.  It only says that our device must deliver 6 lpm of oxygen for a minimum of 15 minutes.  This is exactly what our LifefloTM  OTC device is designed to do.

So if oxygen is so important during an emergency why isn’t it already available?  Excellent question and the answer is quite basic – simple and affordable.  There are several devices on the market that are able to deliver medical oxygen during an emergency by laypersons.  Unfortunately they do not meet 2 critical factors - SIMPLE and AFFORDABLE.  Pressurized cylinders and complicated regulators don’t actually spell SIMPLE.  Also, many of the oxygen devices currently sold for emergency use by laypersons cost well in excess of $350.

Lifeflo’s design combines several technological breakthroughs, central of which are the unique chemistry of the materials used to produce the oxygen.  Furthermore the design breakthroughs allow for simplified shipping and storage until needed.  All totaled the world has not seen a quantum leap in an oxygen producing device when all is considered – simplicity and affordability.  Simply pour stored water into the Oxygen Generation Bag, attach dosing cap, press and begin making oxygen instantly!


“There is no medical emergency that cannot benefit from the delivery of oxygen... I have never seen a device so simple in both its design and operation yet so impactful.” 

LifefloTM Oxygen Generation Technology (OGT) has been in development since 2007.  Initial funding for the technology was under a DOD Naval Research grant.  The challenge of providing potentially lifesaving oxygen to injured soldiers involved strapping a heavy pressurized cylinder to the backs of medics and then dodging bullets.  Needless to say it was not done very often.  The military recognizes the importance of delivering oxygen at the point of injury and is still searching for solutions.

After the initial efforts to produce a device suitable for military purposes the technology began the long journey to where it is now.  Input came from prominent emergency room physicians, former NASA jet propulsion scientists, professors of Chemistry and thought leaders in the field of respiratory medicine.  It has not been an easy path but the core investors and founders have such a strong belief in the technologies ability to change the world they continued to keep the project alive.

The product has gone from a very simple concept to a very difficult and expensive to build device and back to a very simple device.  Don’t let the simplicity fool you in to thinking it is not technical.  To the contrary some of the most significant “simple” devices in fact utilize some very sophisticated science like a recently released $9.00 computer.  The LifefloTM Oxygen Generation Technology is simple in its design for a very good reason – in many instances it will be used when emotions and tensions are high.   

Q&A 

20 Common Questions About Emergency Oxygen

1.) Why is supplemental oxygen so important during a medical emergency? Life-threatening medical emergencies are usually accompanied by low tissue oxygen levels (not enough oxygen to tissue and organs). If this progresses, the brain will begin to die first, with other organs following. Additionally, low oxygen levels to the heart may lead to cardiac arrest. After AIRWAY, supplemental oxygen is the most important first step in treatment.

2.) Who should receive emergency medical oxygen? ANY victim of a potentially life-threatening illness or injury – without exception.

3.) How is emergency oxygen employed? For the victim who is breathing, emergency oxygen via a mask increases the oxygen concentration of the inhaled air. For the victim who requires rescue breathing, emergency oxygen fed into a CPR mask enriches the oxygen concentration of the breath being blown into the victim by the rescuer. In either case, the amount of oxygen available to the victim is greatly increased.

4.) When should emergency oxygen be started? Oxygen should be started IMMEDIATELY AFTER a clear and open AIRWAY is established. However, if there is a delay retrieving the oxygen unit and CPR is required, conventional mouth-to-mouth (or mouth-to-barrier) rescue breathing should be performed until the oxygen unit is available.

5.) Can oxygen ever be harmful during a medical emergency? Oxygen is NEVER harmful during a medical emergency. It increases the likelihood of a better outcome for the victim. The potential harmful effects of oxygen occur after prolonged use (more than 5 hours). The medical literature and publications now state that oxygen DOES NOT suppress respiratory drive (in COPD), and is important to almost all victims of sudden life-threatening illness or injury.

6.) Will emergency oxygen substitute for rescue breathing? NO! In the non-breathing victim, application of oxygen without rescue breathing will not benefit the victim. It must be coupled to the rescue breathing via a CPR mask.

7.) Is oxygen still needed after the arrest victim revives from CPR?/AED? YES! Oxygen should be continued until the EMS arrives. Maintaining oxygen on the revived victim may prevent relapse into cardio-respiratory arrest.

8.) Is oxygen still needed after the victim who is breathing improves or “recovers”? Yes, Oxygen should be continued until the EMS arrives. Maintaining oxygen on the apparently improved or recovered victim may prevent lapse into cardio-respiratory arrest.

9.) Will emergency oxygen substitute for the Heimlich Maneuver ? No. The airway must be cleared of the obstructing food or object. Oxygen alone will not help the victim. Once the obstruction is cleared (A=AIRWAY), oxygen should be applied to aid in recovery.

10.) If I am not sure whether the victim is breathing, should I perform rescue breathing or should I put the oxygen mask on the victim and wait and see what happens? If it is unclear whether or not the victim is breathing, start rescue breathing (preferably with emergency oxy-gen). By responding in this manner, you will not harm the person if he/she is breathing. Do not just put the oxygen mask on and “wait and see”. If they are not breathing or breathing inadequately they may deteriorate to full arrest without rescue breathing.

11.) If the victim has not had a respiratory or cardiac arrest but appears to have difficulty breathing, should I apply emergency oxygen? YES. If the victim has labored breathing, applying emergency oxygen is one of the most important responses you can make to potentially prevent an arrest.

12.) If the victim cannot tolerate the oxygen mask on his/her face, what should I do? Hold the mask just adjacent to the face. Most of the oxygen will still get into the victim’s mouth and nose.

13.) Does emergency oxygen require a doctor's prescription? NO. Oxygen is a drug when it is given in concentrations beyond what is in ambient air and when used for medical treatment. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA), the regulating government agency for medical oxygen, requires a prescription, but has EXEMPTED this requirement for emergency applications. For all other medical applications, Rx Only”. In order to be considered as an over-the-counter (OTC) device, i.e., “non-prescription”, the oxygen delivery system must provide a minimum flow rate of 6 liters per minute for a minimum of 15 minutes.

14.) Who can provide emergency oxygen? Anyone properly instructed in its use.  Providers should be familiar with the manufacturer’s directions and instructional materials. A course in first aid oxygen administration is encouraged.

15.) What are the legal requirements for maintaining a LifefloTM OTC emergency oxygen unit? Unlike oxygen cylinders LifefloTM OTC Emergency Oxygen units require no ongoing maintenance or recertification.  When the expiration date is reached discard per the instructions provided with your device.

16.) Is oxygen dangerous? Can't it catch fire and explode? Oxygen does not “catch fire” or explode. It supports and accelerates existing combustion. It is contained in a protective bag while being generated with safety features built-in. Oxygen is perfectly safe when properly handled and used for life saving.

17.) How much oxygen should I have on-hand? A good rule of thumb is to determine what the average EMS response time is to your facility and have enough to last twice as long as the response time. In most circumstances, a 30 to 45 minute supply is sufficient.

18.) Does OSHA have any specific regulations regarding emergency oxygen? NO. There are no special instructions or record keeping required.

19.) Is oxygen covered under the Good Samaritan laws? Yes, emergency oxygen administration is considered first aid and is therefore covered under the Good Samaritan Laws.

20.) If I am not sure whether to give emergency oxygen, what should I do? GIVE IT! It is far better to over-use it than to under-use it and miss an opportunity. Remember, it is not harmful and my save a life and/or a brain! 




We want to thank all of donors for their donations and please share the campaign by word of mouth with their family and friends and also via all social media channels available.  We are passionate about saving lives using this very simple and affordable way.  Here is a quick link for you to post and share with your networks: https://igg.me/at/lifeflooxygen

4.)
When should emergency oxygen be started? Oxygen should be started
IMMEDIATELY AFTER a clear and open AIRWAY is established. However, if there is
a delay retrieving the oxygen unit and CPR is required, conventional
mouth-to-mouth (or mouth-to-barrier) rescue breathing should be performed until
the oxygen unit is available. 
5.)
Can oxygen ever be harmful during a medical emergency? Oxygen is
NEVER harmful during a medical emergency. It increases the likelihood of a
better outcome for the victim. The potential harmful effects of oxygen occur
after prolonged use (more than 5 hours). The medical literature and
publications now state that oxygen DOES NOT suppress respiratory drive (in
COPD), and is important to almost all victims of sudden life-threatening
illness or injury. 
6.)
Will emergency oxygen substitute for rescue breathing? NO! In
the non-breathing victim, application of oxygen without rescue breathing will
not benefit the victim. It must be coupled to the rescue breathing via a CPR
mask. 
7.)
Is oxygen still needed after the arrest victim revives from CPR?/AED? YES!
Oxygen should be continued until the EMS arrives. Maintaining oxygen on the
revived victim may prevent relapse into cardio-respiratory arrest. 
8.)
Is oxygen still needed after the victim who is breathing improves or
“recovers”? Yes,
Oxygen should be continued until the EMS arrives. Maintaining oxygen on the
apparently improved or recovered victim may prevent lapse into
cardio-respiratory arrest. 
9.)
Will emergency oxygen substitute for the Heimlich Maneuver ? No. The
airway must be cleared of the obstructing food or object. Oxygen alone will not
help the victim. Once the obstruction is cleared (A=AIRWAY), oxygen should be
applied to aid in recovery. 
10.)
If I am not sure whether the victim is breathing, should I perform rescue
breathing or should I put the oxygen mask on the victim and wait and see what
happens? If
it is unclear whether or not the victim is breathing, start rescue breathing
(preferably with emergency oxy-gen). By responding in this manner, you will not
harm the person if he/she is breathing. Do not just put the oxygen mask on and
“wait and see”. If they are not breathing or breathing inadequately they may
deteriorate to full arrest without rescue breathing. 
11.)
If the victim has not had a respiratory or cardiac arrest but appears to have
difficulty breathing, should I apply emergency oxygen? YES. If
the victim has labored breathing, applying emergency oxygen is one of the most
important responses you can make to potentially prevent an arrest. 
12.)
If the victim cannot tolerate the
oxygen mask on his/her face, what should I do? Hold the
mask just adjacent to the face. Most of the oxygen will still get into the
victim’s mouth and nose. 
13.)
Does emergency oxygen require a doctor's prescription? NO.
Oxygen is a drug when it is given in concentrations beyond what is in ambient
air and when used for medical treatment. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA), the regulating government agency for medical
oxygen, requires a prescription, but has EXEMPTED this requirement for
emergency applications. For all other medical applications, Rx Only”. In order
to be considered as an over-the-counter (OTC) device, i.e., “non-prescription”,
the oxygen delivery system must provide a minimum flow rate of 6 liters per
minute for a minimum of 15 minutes. 
14.)
Who can provide emergency oxygen? Anyone properly instructed in its use.  Providers should be familiar with the
manufacturer’s directions and instructional materials. A course in first aid
oxygen administration is encouraged. 
15.)
What are the legal requirements for maintaining a LifefloTM OTC emergency
oxygen unit? Unlike
oxygen cylinders LifefloTM OTC Emergency Oxygen units require no
ongoing maintenance or recertification.  When
the expiration date is reached discard per the instructions provided with your device.
16.)
Is oxygen dangerous? Can't it catch fire and explode? Oxygen
does not “catch fire” or explode. It supports and accelerates existing
combustion. It is contained in a protective bag while being generated with
safety features built-in. Oxygen is perfectly safe when properly handled and
used for life saving. 
17.)
How much oxygen should I have on-hand? A good rule of thumb is to
determine what the average EMS response time is to your facility and have enough
to last twice as long as the response time. In most circumstances, a 30 to 45
minute supply is sufficient. 
18.)
Does OSHA have any specific regulations regarding emergency oxygen? NO. There
are no special instructions or record keeping required. 
19.)
Is oxygen covered under the Good Samaritan laws? Yes,
emergency oxygen administration is considered first aid and is therefore
covered under the Good Samaritan Laws. 
20.)
If I am not sure whether to give emergency oxygen, what should I do? GIVE IT!
It is far better to over-use it than to under-use it and miss an opportunity.
Remember, it is not harmful and my save a life and/or a brain! 














We want to thank all of donors for their donations and please share the campaign by word of mouth with their family and friends and also via all social media channels available.  We are passionate about saving lives using this very simple and affordable way.  Here is a quick link for you to post and share with your networks: https://igg.me/at/lifeflooxygen

story:
TenCar is attempting to raise funds for a clinical study and to receive customer feedback from people like you. This campaign will enable us to complete the final phase of gathering the essential data to bring you the best possible product.  Please help us by donating today.



We value your feedback.  Please complete a brief survey to help refine the final versions of the Choice Cap System.  

There is now a secure choice for ostomates to better manage the activities of everyday living. The Choice Cap provides the needed security and confidence to lead an active lifestyle.

A part of you is always thinking about your ostomy; Am I moving too much? Does my pouch need to be emptied? Did I just smell something? Am I inconveniencing my partner? The active life you led before having to undergo an ileostomy or colostomy came to an abrupt halt while you tried to make sense of, and understand, what you now can and cannot do.  Our founder and the medical professionals on the advisory board at TenCar have seen first-hand how these procedures affect people.

With the advent of The Choice Cap, Tencar has developed and produced a system that is simple to use and secure enough to enable you to resume an active lifestyle. Equipped with a firm outer cap and a locking attachment mechanism, you can return to the activities that make up YOUR active lifestyle.  Activities with your children, social functions, walking,  exercise, physical work, or  intimacy - you can gain the assurance that your ostomy device is secure from leakage or detachment. Just the freedom to be yourself again.

========================================================

Statement from the Founder

People don't often talk about it. The "young" are "too young to believe it's happening" ... 
Seniors feel "suddenly old" .... 
With all the available technology, I was just stunned that NOTHING's been done in a generation...but every day's a new day. 

In my career as a Registered Nurse, I often see people on the worst day of their lives. I've witnessed so many confident, vibrant people struggle with anxiety and depression when faced with this. They avoid social situations, activity and intimacy. All the things that make life worth-while and frankly all the things that'll help them see this through, recover, and enjoy life to the fullest. 

The Choice Cap™ will provide the security ostomates need, knowing the incidents of a colostomy bag coming loose will not occur, allowing them to return to those activities and social settings they once enjoyed! 

It is not intended that the Cap be placed for extended periods of time and may be used with or without the pouch, it can be worn up to several hours, depending on the users' bowel habits. The length of time between emptying will vary. 

The Choice Cap™ system may not be for everyone. We at Tencar, Inc. are all about the "CHOICE" and understand many ostomates struggles to find a product that fits into their existing lifestyle. 

Our Mission is to provide a high quality product for those who are looking for a "Choice" in the products they use that will allow them to comfortably return to the active, social lifestyle they once enjoyed, and Improve the Quality of their Life!

story:
We've Got Your Back!

1 in 4 Health Care and E.M.S. personnel will have a career ending back injury within their first 4 years of employment.  Our mission is to eliminate those potential back injuries from non-emergent lift assists that are performed everyday.

Mike Pannucci, firefighter/paramedic almost had that career ending backing injury while performing a non-emergent lift assist on a heavy patient.  After that point, he knew he had to make a difference and reached out to long time friend, Bobby Clark, to help develop the industries first portable lift assist device.

The Pro-Lift LX is lightweight and portable, can be deployed in a matter of minutes by one or two people, and can comfortably lift a patient weighing up to 500 pounds from the ground to a standing position, into a chair, into a wheelchair, or onto a stretcher with just a pull of a trigger, all in a matter of minutes. 

Our Goal

Our goal is to raise $50,000 which will be used in the following way:

  • Manufacturing of our Pro-Lift LX model for inventory to reduce ship time to our clients.
  • Attend trade shows around the country for E.M.S., Hospital, Nursing Homes, and Funeral Homes.
  • Publication marketing to educate our markets on PLAD's product offerings.
  • Finish prototyping our expandable Pro-Lift that will fit around hospital beds.

Compact, Lightweight, and Portable

Crafted from aircraft grade aluminum, the Pro-Lift LX has a lifting capacity of 500 lbs. while maintaining a compact and lightweight design, and industry first.

Multiple Harness Configurations

Our swing harness can be used in conjunction with our back harness to comfortably and safely lift a patient into a seated position then lowered into a chair or wheelchair.

Backboard Harness System

The backboard harness system allows a single operator to lift a patient on a backboard with just the pull of a trigger.  The Pro-Lift LX accommodates the industry leading stretchers which allows the operator to safely lower the patient directly onto a stretcher.

Lifting Sequence

Pro-Lift LX Features

           
Variable speed lithium ion Smart
Controller with load indicator and 
battery status.		   Multi-position deployment to fit
diverse lifting situations.
     
 
Comfortable patient handles gives
the patient a sense of security
while being lifted.		   Adjustable harness system with
replaceable neoprene support
pads.

The Impact of Your Contribution

Most of us have a friend or family member in the health care and E.M.S. field.  Our product will directly impact them by creating a safe work environment and greatly cut down on injuries from patient lifting.  Back injuries in these fields cost in the billions of dollars yearly which impacts each and every one of us indirectly.  We want to bring the dollar amount down while saving backs, one lift at a time!

Other Ways to Contribute

We understand that some of you are unable to monetarily contribute, and we completely understand.  We would be flattered if you shared our mission with your friends and on your social media accounts.  This will go a long way in informing others that may have the potential of injuring themselves while performing non-emergent lift assists!

story:
Short Summary

  • As Treasure Coast Orthopedics' part of ongoing efforts to improve access to affordable orthopedic healthcare in Vero Beach and the surrounding areas, we provide care to those who have been injured and do not have accessibility to specialists.

  • We are focused on diagnosing and treating orthopaedic and physiatric conditions of people of all ages while emphasizing preventative medicine and their overall health and wellness.

What We Need & What You Get

  • The goal is to raise $50k to help us continue to provide quality care to the local community throughout 2015. The funds are used to cover the costs generated running the business and treating patients who have been injured and unable to afford orthopedic and physiatric care. 
  • We offer minor procedures in our office, but only after both risks and benefits have been thoroughly explained and understood and written consent has been obtained from the patient. 

Risks & Challenges

  • We have overcome most obstacles as that we have been operating for over a year and working to continue for more to come.
  • We work with some professionals who volunteer their time to provide quality care to our patients.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Neither healthcare nor health insurance is cheap. Let your friends and loved ones know that there is help when they are in need.

story:
Short Summary

Super Short Version: The Only Alarm In The World That Will Pay You If You Can't Get Up Early!

An Apple Watch Alarm That Uses Your Heartbeat To Wake You Up 

Hey, I'm Parker, an avid entrepreneur and lover of life...who has struggled in the past to wake up early...even though I knew the many benefits associated with waking up early...I just couldn't do it. So I developed a simple theory...and tested it...

  • To wake up early you have to know about Newton's Laws of Motion
  • Objects at rest (me while sleeping) will stay at rest (me over-sleeping)
  • Objects in motion will remain in motion...but how do you go from resting to in-motion?

Well...unlike most alarm clocks that give your tired-self the option to go back to sleep...I simply removed that option and invented a 100% fool-proof way to get myself up and moving in the early morning...

So I invented an Apple Watch alarm clock that we're calling WakeUpBeats that only shuts-off when your heart rate goes over 100 Beats Per Minute for 60 seconds...

Once you're up and moving, you won't be able to go back to sleep and the best part is that you won't even want to!

What We Need & What You Get

So here's what we need:

  • $10,000 is our goal. This will pretty much cover development costs and justify to us that there other people out there (that's you) that think this is cool and worth creating.
  • If you decide to fund us you'll get some really unique perks...lifetime access to WakeUpBeats plus access to future enhancements for life...plus you'll be helping to make the world a better, more productive place.
  • If you use WakeUpBeats and it doesn't get you up in the morning...we'll actually pay you! We offer a 110% Money Back Wake-Up Guarantee!
  • If we don't reach our funding goal, the funds will be either returned or we will continue on with development with a somewhat "simpler" version WakeUpBeats (we'll leave that choice up to you)

The Impact

Your contribution will help us with our mission to make the world a better more productive place...to help people attain the only thing they can't buy...time.

  • Just imagine if only 1,000 people use WakeUpBeats to get up one hour earlier...In one year that equals 15,208 extra days of productivity! Imagine the possibilities!
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Possible Risks & Obstacles

Let's face it...every new venture has some risk...and we'd rather be open with you about it and upfront...Possible obstacles include...

  • Development delays...you never know...but in the past...we've kept it simple, foucsed on our goal, and shipped on time
  • Apple policies and regulations...more than anything this would likely delay the launch of WakeUpBeats
  • Technology limitations...the Apple Watch platform and iOS platforms allow for alot so we don't see this being a problem but we want to list it just to make you aware. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • If you can't Back This Project...we ask that you tweet about it or simply share via Facebook. 
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

Thank You So Much!

story:
The Issue

My cause is to raise money that will directly affect the lives of almost 150 children currently living in Ghana.  Ghana is considered a financially poor country in West Africa that struggles to provide many of the things that we hold dear here in North America, especially access to affordable healthcare.  One surgical procedure considered to be relatively routine here is considered extraordinarily expensive for Ghanaian's, many of who live on $1 a day. 

One hundred and fifty children are still on the waiting list of the Cardiothoracic Centre of the Korle Bu Teaching Hospital in Ghana to undergo hole-in-heart surgery due to financial challenges.

Although the government takes care of half of the cost of the surgery, the parents of the children with hole-in-heart cases are unable to pay for the rest to enable their children to undergo the surgery.

The cost of the surgery differs from case to case, depending on the complexity of the operation. Thus the cost to be borne by the child (or his/her parent) would range from six thousand Ghana Cedis (GhC6,000.00) to nine thousand Ghana Cedis (GhC9,000.00), depending on the complexity of the case.  At current exchange rates, that equates to a staggering $1500-$2500 US dollars per child.

Simply put, I consider Ghana to be my second home and I would like to do anything I can to help give these children a chance of a normal healthy life.  The reality is that the prognosis for many of these children is not good.

What I can do

If I reach my goal, I think i can pay the other half of the surgery for ~10 children.  If I go over my goal, more children will have a chance at life! 

There are many causes that we all contribute to but never know the impact.  Contribute to my campaign to help at least some of these children not only survive, but thrive.

story:
Dear friends, 

As some of you may know, Luc and I have been travelling in Nepal and fortunately returned to the UK just before the devastating earthquake. 

Story

Our Nepali host, Narayan  and Ganesh, our trekking guide in the Himalayas are now working with a group of volunteers that includes doctors and nurses trying to reach remote villages in Nepal where help has not yet arrived and provide food, water, medical care and tents. 

The group have just completed their relief campaign in the Kalleri village  (Dhading district) and are now gearing up for their next destinations: 

In Kalleri, all 106 households were completely destroyed .The team was able to rescue some injured people and take them to  Pokhara (the nearers city) for further treatment.

The Impact

Following last Saturday's 7.8 magnitude earthquake, more than 6 000 people have died and over 13 000 are injured.  Homes have been flattened, ancient monuments destroyed and deadly avlanches and landslides have been set of making some of the affected areas very difficult to reach. 

The relief efforts are now turning into a race against time due to the imminence of the monsoon season. 

Message from Narayan 

"Earthquake Relief camping in Kalleri Dhading has completed. There was complete distruction of village consisting 106 houses. We were the first rescue team reached there for first time. Villagers were so happy to welcome us even they were in complete disaster.
The next purposed plan is any village which was completely distructed by the earthquake. We are planning to move on saturday. Our appeal to everyone is raise the fund for earthquake victim". 

All donations are guaranteed to reach this extraordinary group of volunteers.
